function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Physical activity may ameliorate pathological outcomes of upper respiratory tract infections (URTI), including COVID-19, by reducing excessive local inflammation and inducing the secretion of anti-inflammatory cytokines.","Impact":"If physical activity is not promoted, there may be an increased risk of excessive inflammation and prolonged T helper type 1 (Th1) cell population activity, leading to cell damage and necrosis.","Mitigation":"Promote regular physical activity to reduce the risk of excessive inflammation and cytokine activity.","Technologies":"Health and fitness tracking technologies, online exercise programs.","People":"Individuals at risk of URTI, including those at risk of COVID-19 infection.","Owner":"Health organizations, fitness professionals, individuals"},{"Description":"Physical activity can be effective in ameliorating mental well-being and preventing symptoms of mental health disorders such as depression and anxiety.","Impact":"Without adequate physical activity, there may be an increased risk of mental health disorders and reduced mental well-being.","Mitigation":"Encourage regular physical activity to support mental well-being and prevent mental health disorders.","Technologies":"Mental health tracking apps, online counseling services.","People":"Individuals at risk of mental health disorders and reduced well-being.","Owner":"Mental health professionals, individuals"},{"Description":"Examination of changes in physical activity levels during self-quarantine may provide insight into the impact of restrictions on physical activity and its correlation with individual well-being.","Impact":"Without understanding the impact of self-quarantine on physical activity and well-being, it may be challenging to address the needs of individuals during similar situations in the future.","Mitigation":"Conduct surveys and studies to monitor changes in physical activity levels during self-quarantine and evaluate their correlation with well-being.","Technologies":"Online survey platforms, activity tracking apps.","People":"Individuals affected by self-quarantine and similar restrictions, public health organizations.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health organizations"}]}
